title: Former Arizona / Miami cornerback transfers to UVA
body_text:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL
Former Arizona and Miami cornerback Emmanuel Karnley has signed with the University of Virginia out of the transfer portal, UVA announced Wednesday.
Karnley, a 6-foot-3, 185-pound Walnut Creek, California, native, had ranked as the best available player in the portal, according to Matt Zenitz of CBS Sports.
A three-star recruit out of high school, Karnley transferred to Miami after last season. He decided to enter the portal again, though, this spring after not playing a game with the Hurricanes.
- Tuscarora High defensive lineman Lucas Allen announced on X that he has committed to William & Mary.
COLLEGE BASKETBALL
Hokies land guard from UNLV
Former UNLV guard Jailen Bedford will play for Virginia Tech next season, the Hokies announced Wednesday.
The 6-4, 180-pound Bedford, from Austin, Texas, averaged 10.2 points and 4.3 rebounds for the Runnin’ Rebels last season. He scored in double figures in 10 of his final 11 contests.
Bedford started his college career at Trinidad State, where he averaged 16.6 points per game.
Report: UVA gains 7-foot transfer
Virginia landed a commitment from former Kansas State center Ugonna Onyenso, a 7-foot, 245-pound Nigerian who averaged 2.8 points, 2.4 rebounds and 0.9 blocks per game last season.
For Kentucky in the 2023-24 season, he averaged 3.6 points, 4.8 rebounds and 2.8 blocks in 24 games.
Report: Ex-UVA assistant heads to Georgetown
Former Virginia associate head coach Jason Williford is being hired by Georgetown coach Ed Cooley, according to reporter Jeff Goodman.
Williford, a former UVA player who grew up in Richmond, was a key assistant coach under Tony Bennett for more than a decade and for Ron Sanchez last season.
Former Tribe guard chooses ECU
Guard Isaiah Mbeng, who played as a freshman for William & Mary, committed to transfer to East Carolina. He averaged 5.7 points, 3.4 assists, 1.5 steals and 19.9 minutes per game for the Tribe.
COLLEGE SWIMMING
UVA’s Walsh earns ACC honor
University of Virginia standout Gretchen Walsh has been named the ACC Scholar-Athlete of the Year for women’s swimming and diving for the second straight year.
It is the sixth consecutive year a Cavalier has been selected for the award. Kate Douglass won it in 2022 and 2023, and Paige Madden received the honor in 2020 and 2021.
COLLEGE LACROSSE
CNU women reach C2C final
No. 2 seed Christopher Newport (8-10) defeated No. 3 seed Mary Washington 19-11 in a semifinal of the Coast-to-Coast Athletic Conference women’s lacrosse tournament Wednesday. UMW finished 11-7.
Junior Brookelyn Morrison set career highs with six goals and nine points. Faith O’Connor finished with seven points, while Grace Taylor had six, including four assists. Elena Sorkin scored her fifth hat trick of the year.
The Captains will visit No. 1 seed Salisbury in the championship match at 1 p.m. Saturday.
- William & Mary lacrosse standout Paige Gilbert has earned second-team all-conference honors from the CAA. The Doylestown, Pennsylvania, native led the Tribe in goals (37), points (56) and draw controls (60) and ranked second on the team in assists (19).
- Hampton University has decided not to renew the contract of men’s lacrosse coach Chazz Woodson. He took over the team in 2022 and guided the transition from independent to Southern Conference and now the Coastal Athletic Association. His teams went 0-50 in four years.
- Hampton defender Zion Garcia made the All-CAA second team, and teammate Alex Lacey made the all-rookie team.
COLLEGE SOFTBALL
NSU is No. 2 seed for MEAC tourney
Norfolk State has earned the No. 2 seed in the MEAC Tournament, which the Spartans will host May 7-10.
The Spartans are 21-21 overall and 14-7 in the MEAC — a marked improvement from last year’s 4-42 record.
Howard earned the No. 1 seed with 20-1 league record. Delaware State is the No. 3 seed, followed by Morgan State, North Carolina Central and South Carolina State.
COLLEGE BASEBALL
VMI rallies from nine down, ends Tribe’s winning streak at six
Boston Torres drove a walk-off three-run homer to right field in the ninth inning to give VMI a 12-9 comeback victory over William & Mary before 1,151 in the inaugural Peninsula Classic at War Memorial Stadium in Hampton.
W&M (19-25) led 9-0 entering the bottom of the seventh but never scored again against the Keydets (26-20), who ended the Tribe’s six-game winning streak.
Tribe center fielder Ben Parker went 3 for 5 with two RBIs, extending his hitting streak to 30 games. Jerry Barnes III went 3 for 4 with two runs and two RBIs.
VMI’s Grayson Fitzwater, a former Nansemond River High star, was 4 for 5 with three runs and four RBIs.
- Virginia 9, VCU 8: Henry Ford hit a three-run homer to cap a six-run fourth inning as the Cavaliers outlasted the Rams on Tuesday night in Charlottesville. Ford finished 3 for 4 and Aidan Teel and James Nunnallee each added two hits and two RBIs for UVA (25-16). Casey Kleinman hit a three-run homer for VCU (14-30).
- Liberty 13, Virginia Tech 4: Michael Gibson had three hits and three RBIs and Nick Barone went 4 for 4 with three runs as the Flames (26-19) routed the Hokies (27-18) on Tuesday night in Blacksburg.
COLLEGE GOLF
UVA men make Reno Regional
The Virginia men’s golf team earned the No. 2 seed in the NCAA Reno Regional, which will be held May 12-14 at Montreux Golf & Country Club in Nevada.
The top five teams and the low individual not on those teams from each regional will advance to the NCAA finals, which will take place May 23-28 at Omni La Costa Resort & Spa in Carlsbad, California.
Texas is the No. 1 seed in the regional.
